Prevention and Control
"Constant exposure to noise emitted by vehicles and machines (boat engine, Oyster washing machines and high pressure washers) and water movements."
"Exposure to ultraviolet radiation from the sun."

"Elimination or replacement: • Working in covered areas and protected from the sun.
Engineering controls: N/A
Administrative and PPE: • Wear sunscreen, hats and sunglasses; \n • Reduce exposure to sunlight with work rotation; \n • Perform skin examinations at suspect points."
"Burns; \n Disability as a result of serious sequelae; \n Death."
"Intense exposure to the sun at very high temperatures because of outdoor work; \n Long exposure to very low temperatures, wind, rain and water."
"Exposure during the occurrence of rainfall; \n Exposure to seawater, tanks and ponds; \n Exposure to water used in cleaning and damp locations."
"Skin disease (irritant dermatitis); \n Slips, trips and falls."

"Elimination or replacement: N/A
Engineering controls: • Building barriers that avoid direct contact with moisture.
Administrative and PPE: • Intervals between activities; \n • Minimize wet work to less than 2 hours; \n • Wear personal protective equipment (PPE) such as gloves, boots, clothing and overalls."
"Earth moving and dust forming jobs; \n Improper care of equipment; \n Precarious maintenance of boat engines."
"Fainting; \n Dizziness; \n Skin and respiratory irritation."

"Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is the ability of a microorganism (like bacteria, viruses, and some parasites) to stop an antimicrobial (such as antibiotics, antivirals and antimalarials) from working against it. As a result, standard treatments become ineffective, infections persist and may spread to others; \n Aquacultural workers: handling fish, molluscs, crustaceans - in ponds, lakes, rivers, wetlands and coastal or offshore waters."
"Handling or activities that promote direct unintentional contact with pathogens; \n Contact through contaminated water; \n Contact through interaction with animals."
"Infections; \n Diseases."

"Venomous Handling fish with sharp teeth or spines that can cause cuts and stings; \n Poisonous snakes, and scorpions, spiders, caterpillars, mosquitos, wasps and bees present in vegetation and water. \n
Wild Bites and attacks of alligators and other animals (in regions favorable to the appearance of these animals)."

"Elimination or replacement: N/A
Engineering controls: • Setting traps to catch venomous animals and insects.
Administrative and PPE: • Control of vegetation around tanks and installations; \n • Put in sight emergency phones and local poisoning centers; \n • Closed shoes and gloves for animal handling."
"Work-related anxiety, depression, and stress."

"Elimination or replacement: N/A
Engineering controls: N/A
Administrative and PPE: • Worker education and training focused on the worker\"s quality of life.
"Working hours longer than 8 hours per day or greater than 44 hours per week; \n Little rest time or intervals."
"Tiredness and fatigue leading to poor attention and decreased productivity; \n Muscle aches."

"Elimination or replacement: • Maintain adequate working hours.
Engineering controls: N/A \n Administrative and PPE: • "Better work organization."
"Working at night with low visibility."

"Elimination or replacement: • Change work to be done during daylight hours.
Engineering controls: • Provide adequate lighting and backup lighting.
Administrative and PPE: • Limit night work to as few hours as possible."
"Tractor overturning/Tractor rollover \n Miscellaneous incidents with machines, aerators and equipment; \n Machines without protective equipment."

"Slips and falls can be caused by wet and slippery floors, tools left on runways, and discarded debris on the floor, such as oysters and open gutters; \n Falls from heights, floating or fixed plataforms."
"Falls at sea or dams; \n Lack of use of the Personal Flotation Device (PFD); \n Diving."
"Handling of syringe and needle in vaccination."

"Elimination or replacement: • Install automatic vaccination equipment.
Engineering controls: • Use corrugated table to immobilize the fish during vaccination.
Administrative and PPE: • Vaccine training; \n • Use of Personal Protective Equipment such as anti-cutting gloves (high strength polyurethane); \n • Well equipped first aid kit."
"Your highest note: "
You have not filled out the checklist yet.

Occupational Health is responsible for prevention and protection of people\'s health, acting in actions aimed at the promotion and preservation of their health. To help you - and encourage - we set up this general inspection checklist:
Fill Checklist
Review last result
General Checklist
Management Checklist
Workers Checklist
OK
Select the practices adopted at your workplace
I use personal protective equipment such as gloves, caps, sunscreen, masks and lifejackets.
The vegetation around tanks and facilities is often cut.
Often pest and vector control is performed.
The workplace is clean and organized.
All electrical equipment is waterproof, has a fuse and proper ground connection.
To avoid drowning, workers use lifebuoys or lifejackets in contact with water.
To avoid prolonged exposures to different hazards, there are frequent breaks and rotation of workers.
OSH risks in the workplace have been identified.
Loads transported by the worker are assessed to avoid workers lifting excessive weight.
People involved in the production process were sufficiently trained for their functions.
As appropriate for their duties, workers should be able to swim and have necessary diving qualifications.
When working with chemicals, workers use appropriate masks and gloves.
Workers are advised to have some type of immunization (tetanus, hepatitis A and B, typhoid, influenza and / or yellow fever).
In my work environment, it is possible to take breaks or change of position after long periods of activity.
I use cut resistant gloves when handling equipment or sharp machines.
Equipment or machines in my workplace have a "lock switch" not to be triggered during handling.
Workers are aware of their health and safety responsibilities and have they been warned of any potential hazards (physical, chemical, ergonomic, health, biological) that they may encounter at work.
Only authorized and trained personnel can operate tools and equipment or use chemicals.
There are opportunities for professional training and familiarization for new workers.
There are experienced and responsible workers to turn to if other workers need assistance.

Check out some tips based on your markups to increase the level of health and safety:
You work in a place appropriate!
"You work in a place "
Your highest score:
Always wear personal protective equipment to ensure your health and safety.
Keep the vegetation always low to avoid hiding and abundance of animals
Take pest control periodically to prevent insects, rodents and other animals or disease vectors in the workplace.
Clean and organized work environment avoids damage to the workers\' health and influence on the quality of the company.
Use of fuses, waterproofed and grounded electrical installations reduces the risk of electric shock.
The use of lifebuoys, lines or lifejackets in water contact activities prevents drowning and possible deaths.
Jobs having some type of prolonged exposure to workplace hazards should be accompanied by frequent breaks and rotation of workers to avoid immediate or long term health problems.
Signaling in the workplace helps to prevent risks and should be used to warn of possible hazards or dangers.

Use mechanical equipment to eliminate or reduce physical exertion. Use pulley, rail or crane to raise nets in the warehouse or transport loads. If the load carried is excess weight, the excess load must be removed in order to avoid future health problems and accidents.
Personnel involved in aquaculture activities should use specific PPE and receive training and updates for their functions.
Knowing how to swim or dive can assist to avoid drownings.

The use of masks and gloves when handling chemicals is necessary to avoid poisoning and burns. Check the product instruction manual for correct use of protective equipment. Whenever possible, replace toxic or lethal products. Chemicals should be stored in a well-ventilated area away from incompatible substances.

Most countries do not have a special regulation of vaccines for aquaculture workers, however, it is recommended that workers who have direct contact with animals and water get vaccinated for Tetanus, Hepatitis A and B, typhoid, influenza and / or yellow fever.
Pauses, maintaining good posture or changes of position during periods of work are essential when tasks are repetitive or need to be performed in a specific position.

Resistant gloves to handle sharp equipment or machines are recommended to avoid cuts and more serious punctures. There are high strength polyurethane gloves on the market that protect the worker against cuts and other injuries.

Locking keys of machinery and equipment must be installed and workers trained and oriented on the requirement of this mechanism to avoid triggering equipment during cleaning or other work. In this way, serious injuries such as limb loss or fatal accidents such as firing furnaces, crushers or cooling chambers (and liken/similar) are avoided when a worker is inside.
Workers should be aware and trained about their health and safety responsibilities as well as the potential risks.
All workers must be trained to operate machines, tools, equipment and chemicals in order to minimize the risk of accidents.
Training of workers is essential.
Experienced workers or professionals are important in advising other workers on the activities.
br.gov.rs.fepagro.aquasafe.preferences
scoreChecklist
stringTopics

Aquasafe is a platform for promoting workers' safety and health in aquaculture, with actions aimed at aquaculture workers and producers, students and professionals.
It addresses the main hazards and associated health risks in aquaculture work environments. Information on prevention, use of safety equipment and damage to health is also available in the app.
AquaSafe can be used in the assessment of occupational risks through a checklist and other tools. It assists in the decision making of injury and disease prevention methods, techniques or measures through providing information on eliminating or reducing risks, engineering controls and/or administrative controls and use of PPE.
Learning can be assessed through an interactive quiz.

AquaSafe Application
Floating Equipment
Protective Clothing
Eye protection
Hearing protection
Sign protection (CPE)
Fire protection (CPE)
First aid (CPE)
Electrical shock protection
Chemical protection
Diving protection

Occupational risk is the probability of occurrence of an adverse health effect due to exposure to a hazard (OHSAS 18001). In aquaculture activities, workers are exposed to different hazards, which may be physical, chemical, biological, ergonomic and psychosocial. To eliminate, avoid or mitigate health risks related to these hazards, it is necessary to establish hazard control and risk management. \nThe classification of risks may vary according to the legislation of each country.\n

According to occupational health and safety bodies, effective controls protect workers from workplace hazards. There is a wealth of information to help employers investigate options for controlling identified hazards. Before selecting any control measure, it is essential to request information from stakeholders (workers and employers) on their feasibility and effectiveness.
 
 • Employers should select the most viable, effective and permanent controls.

 • Select controls according to a hierarchy that emphasizes solutions including elimination or replacement first, followed by safe work practices, administrative controls, and finally personal protective equipment.

 • Avoid selecting controls that can directly or indirectly introduce new hazards.

Life jacket" • The lifejacket should allow the person to wear it correctly and quickly; be comfortable; resistant to different types of water, temperatures and faults;be provided with an oxidation resistant whistle, firmly attached to the vest. • The lifejacket must take into account the weight and size of the user to allow stable buoyancy. • Models with specific shape and volume collar are able to keep the face at a safe distance from the water or untap the person quickly in cases of unconsciousness. Check for models that have this specificity. • Lifejackets are classified and should be used according to the form and conditions of use." \n
\nLifebuoys and lifelines" • The lifebuoys are devices for calm and inner waters in which help is always near. They are not safe for unconscious people or for long periods in the water. • Life lines are used to rescue people in the water or to protect against falls.

Gloves
 • Gloves should be worn when handling animals, products, knives, needles, chemicals and hazardous substances.
 • Wear work gloves if you have injuries, abrasions, or irritations on your hands and arms, except when using them may cause a risk.
 • Rubber gloves can provide protection against moisture and cold.
 • Anti-cutting gloves provide good protection when handling knives or materials with sharp edges.
 • Fabric gloves can be worn underneath for even thermal comfort.
 • When working near a hoist, spear, saw or treadmill, tie long hair and do not wear loose clothing or jewelry.


 Shoes
 • Wear safety boots or shoes with good traction that avoid slipping and falling, as well as when operating vehicles and machines.
 
 Overalls
 • Wear appropriate clothing for the season and task to be performed.
 • Clothing should be protected from prolonged exposure to cold weather, especially if clothing is soaked with water or by direct immersion, which can result in hypothermia, mental and muscular confusion, and death.
 
 Hats and sun protection
 • Workers should wear a hat that holds direct sunlight away from their head, ears and face.
 • They should be protected from direct sunlight and ultraviolet rays using sunscreen.
 
 Wetsuit / diving equipment
 • Each diver must be equipped with a strong, sharp knife; weights with a quick release mechanism which are sufficient to control buoyancy; a diving suit or other protective clothing; and proper protection of the head while conducting a dive, which exposes the diver to risks of falling objects or head injuries.

• Protect eyes with safety or protective eyewear when activity requires eye protection.
 • Workers should wear sunglasses to protect their eyes from direct sunlight or the reflection of water or ice.
 • Do not wear standard sunglasses as a substitute for safety glasses when performing tasks that require the use of eye protection. For these tasks, wear appropriate glasses or protective masks.

• Wear hearing protection (protectors and dampers) when using equipment or noisy machines (whenever the noise level exceeds 80 decibels). A good rule of thumb is if someone else is talking and can not be heard when they are at arm's length, then hearing protection should be used.
 
 • Some of the most common equipment used by fish farmers where hearing protection should be used include a chainsaw (115 decibels), a gasoline engine (100 decibels), a tractor (80-110 decibels), oyster washing machines (> 80 decibels).

Place warning signs and emergency numbers in any chemical or noxious storage area. The signs should be placed according to the risks found in the workplace. 
 
 Here are some examples: 
 

Warning Signs (yellow) 
 • Corrosive substance 
 • Toxic substance 
 • Flammable substance 
 • Harmful or irritant 
 • Vehicles 
 • Electrocution 
 • Fall 
 • Low temperature 
 
 Signs of Obligation (blue) 
 • Use of PPE 
 • Gloves 
 • Mask 
 • Hearing protection 
 
 Emergency Signs (green) 
 • Indicates, in case of danger, emergency exits, the way to the emergency station or where there are life-saving devices. 
 • Emergency Exit 
 
 Prohibition Signs (red) 
 • Warn of a situation or action that may cause damage or risk to the facility. 
 • No smoking 
 • No entry 
 • Do not open the safety device

Fire extinguisher
 • Fire extinguishers must not have expired and should be tested according to the manufacturers specifications.
 • "No smoking" signs should be affixed to all deposits or areas where flammable products are present.
 • Fire extinguishers must be kept fully charged and renewed as specified by the manufacturer.
 • Workers should be trained in the use of fire extinguishers.
 

Types of extinguishers:
 • Chemical powder: suitable for flammable liquids.
 • Carbon dioxide (CO2): suitable for fires of electrical equipment.
 • Water: Suitable for wood fires, fabric, paper and solid materials in general.

• Workers should be trained on first aid measures whenever possible.
 • Keep list of useful telephones visible and a kit for simple procedures.
 
 The First Aid Kit may include:
 • Procedure gloves
 • Sterile gauze
 • Cotton
 • Plaster
 • Neutral Soap
 • Tray
 • Clinical Thermometer
 • Bandages

Safe procedures should be adopted since electricity is an essential component in aquaculture activity. 
 
 • Lock the main switches and place the locks and labels on them before working on power circuits so that no one else can use them while you are working.
 • Periodic electrical inspections by qualified personnel.
 • Allow only qualified personnel to work on electrical repairs and use suitable instruments to test circuits.
 • Make sure wiring, equipment, cables, and plugs are in good condition and grounded.
 • Do not overload your electrical wiring.
 • Ensure that all devices and equipment are properly grounded, especially equipment used in wet areas.
 • When replacing a fuse or circuit breaker, make sure that its rating is correct for the circuit.

The route of exposure or target organ damage of the chemical assists in making decisions about the protective equipment to be used.
 
 Eyes
 • Danger of chemical or metallic splashes, dust, gas and vapor.
 • Wear safety glasses, face shields, suitable visors.
 
 Hands and arms
 • Danger of chemicals
 • Wear gloves, gloves with wrists, mittens and sleeves that cover part or all of the arm. The choice of material should take into account the chemical product handled.
 
 Feet and legs
 • Danger of chemicals
 • Wear safety boots. Appropriate footwear should be selected for identified hazards including oil resistant soles or chemicals.
 
 Lungs
 • Danger of dust, gas and vapors.
 • Wear respiratory protective equipment (RPE). Some respirators rely on the filtering of airborne contaminants in the workplace. These include simple filtering face masks and respirators. The right kind of respiratory filter should be used because each of them is effective only for a limited range of substances.
 
 Whole body
 • Danger of splashes of chemicals.
 • Wear conventional or disposable overalls, aprons.

• The diving equipment must be tested according to the manufacturer's specifications. The diving equipment test record must be maintained. Before use, you should check that it is working properly.
 
 • Dive team members who become aware of a malfunction or risk of diving equipment at the dive site must notify other divers who may be affected by the malfunction immediately. If the fault occurs during a dive and there are no replacements available on site, the dive must be immediately aborted in cooperation with the other members of the dive team.
 
 • Each diver must be equipped with a sharp knife; weights with a quick release mechanism which are sufficient to control buoyancy; a diving suit or other protective clothing; and proper protection of the head while conducting a dive, which exposes the diver to risks of falling objects or head injuries.
 
 • A dive should not be performed if a health and safety hazard can be caused by equipment near the dive site.

Worker Checklist
" 1 - Are the workers members of a union?"
" 2 - Does the union have a member, specifically trained to address health and safety issues at this workplace? "
" 3 - Is there a union-management OHS committee and is it functioning regularly?"
" 4 - Is there a collective bargaining agreement, with provisions on OHS, signed between union and management? "

" 5 - For issues relevant for women, is there a union women's committee at the workplace, or a female union representative, trained to address issues of gender equality, maternity rights and gender based violence? "
Below are some checklists to help you with better management

1 - The dive equipment has been tested according to the manufacturer\'s specifications?
2 - Before using the equipment, a correct function check is performed?
3 - Each diver is always equipped with a knife; weights with a quick release mechanism to control buoyancy; a diving suit or other protective clothing; and proper protection of the head while diving?

4 - If a breakdown or unpredictable situation occurs during a dive and there are no substitutions available on site, is the dive immediately aborted in cooperation with the other members of the dive team?
5 - Will dive team members become aware of a malfunction or risk of diving equipment at the dive site notifying other divers immediately?
1 - Are personal protective equipment (PPE) provided at no cost to workers and employees?
2 - Is collective protection equipment (CPE) available and visible to workers?
3 - Are workers trained in the use and maintenance of individual and collective equipment?
4 - Do workers wear appropriate clothing to protect themselves from extreme temperatures?
5 - Are protective equipment used by workers when handling chemicals?
6 - Do workers wear tight-fitting clothes and tied hair when working near machines?
1 - Are the equipment instruction manuals available to operators?
2 - Are the tractors equipped with a safety cab (ROPS) to prevent crushing or drowning in case of overturning/rollover?
3 - Are the equipment in good mechanical condition and have safety protection to prevent incidents?
4 - Are machine and equipment operators aware of the hazards and risks related to their equipment?
5 - Have operators been trained to use the machines and equipment they use?
6 - Are hydraulic winches lowered at the end of a task and suspended loads never left unattended?
7 - Are proper locking procedures used on machines and equipment?
1 - Are the main switches off, locked, and flagged with labels before starting work on power circuits, so no one else can use them while another is working?
2 - Are periodic electrical inspections done by qualified people?
3 - Only qualified people work on electrical repairs and use appropriate instruments to test circuits?
4 - Wiring, equipment, cables and plugs are in good condition and grounded?
5 - Are workers aware of the procedure in case of contact with power lines?
6 - Does the electrical system have ample capacity to handle all loads?
7 - Do all electrical switches have a locking device to prevent unintentional starting of equipment during maintenance?
1 - Is the vessel used safe and appropriate for the activity?
2 - Are radio and other communication equipment on board and working?
3 - Do workers have equipment and protective clothing, such as thermal protective clothing, lifejackets, or other personal flotation devices?
4 - Are the weather conditions checked before doing any activities at sea?
5 - Are the safety equipment in good working order?
6 - When walking on the vessel, is there a suitable corridor or walkway to prevent workers falling in the sea?
1 - Are chemicals stored appropriately in well ventilated areas and separated from reactable substances?
2 - Are gas leaks detected periodically and repaired?
3 - Are workers trained and aware of chemical hazards in the workplace?
4 - Personal protective equipment (PPE) such as closed-toe shoes, nitrile gloves, goggles, and appropriate masks / respirators are provided and used when handling chemicals?
5 - Warning signs and emergency numbers in chemical or noxious storage areas are available and visible?
1 - Do female workers receive the same wages as men to perform the same function or task?
2 - Are pregnant or breastfeeding workers removed from unhealthy situations and placed in activities of lower potential risk to their health and their baby?
3 - Are breastfeeding breaks allowed or is there any support for breastfeeding women and/or their children?
4 - Do female workers have scheduled breaks during activities with long periods of immersion or exposure to water and/or cold?
5 - Is the manual transport of cargo carried by women less than that allowed for men?
6 - Is there access to a clean bathroom, whenever the worker needs it during working journey?"

Workers Representation and Opportunities

"International protocols and guidelines act as a basis for adapting or creating norms related to animal health and welfare, food safety, environmental integrity and socioeconomic aspects. The FAO and ILO has been doing important work in this direction, establishing guidelines for decent work, eradicating both child labor and modern slave labor, and establishing gender and ethnic minority equity in the concept of Decent Work, as well as developing OHS standards.
" "International Labour Organisation (ILO) Convention No. 184 and Recommendation No. 192 on Safety and Health in Agriculture adopts various proposals concerning health and safety in agriculture.

"

• Identify relevant national laws.
 • Use ILO Convention No. 184 on Safety and Health in Agriculture.
 • Apply standards to problems.

"This is the first time that agriculture health and safety is considered. The convention addresses:
" 
 (1) Health and safety protection for agricultural workers;
 (2) Workers’ rights;
 (3) Employers’ duties (Risk assessment; training and information);
 (4) Government obligations.
 

"Article 7: Employers’ duties regarding risk assessment, training and stopping dangerous operations
The employer shall:
" "a) Carry out appropriate risk assessments in relation to the safety and health of workers and, on the basis of these results, adopt preventive and protective measures to ensure that under all conditions of their intended use, all agricultural activities, workplaces, machinery, equipment, chemicals, tools and processes under the control of the employer are safe and comply with prescribed safety and health standards;
" "b) Ensure that adequate and appropriate training and comprehensible instructions on safety and health and any necessary guidance or supervision are provided to workers in agriculture, including information on the hazards and risks associated with their work and the action to be taken for their protection, taking into account their level of education and differences in language; and
" "c) Take immediate steps to stop any operation where there is an imminent and serious danger to safety and health and to evacuate workers as appropriate.

"
"Article 8: Workers’ rights and duties
Article 8.1. Workers in agriculture shall have the right:
" "(a) To be informed and consulted on safety and health matters including risks from new technologies;
" "(b) To participate in the application and review of safety and health measures and, in accordance with national law and practice, to select safety and health representatives and representatives in safety and health committees; and
" "(c) To remove themselves from danger resulting from their work activity when they have reasonable justification to believe there is an imminent and serious risk to their safety and health and so inform their supervisor immediately. They shall not be placed at any disadvantage as a result of these actions.

"
"Artigo 8.2. Workers in agriculture and their representatives shall have the duty to comply with the prescribed safety and health measures and to co-operate with employers in order for the latter to comply with their own duties and responsibilities.
"

Reference 3 - ILO

The 5 whys technique is simple and serves to identify the root cause of a problem. It consists of identifying a problem and asking (at least) 5 \"why\" questions. The answer to the last why is the root cause of the problem. From the root cause identification, you can find out what action to take to reduce the probability of the problem happening again. The tool should be used with \'good judgment\', when you realize that reached the root of the problem just stop.

Make sure the risks are not avoidable or replaceable. Personal protective equipment (PPE) must be provided free of charge to workers and employees. Collective protective equipment (CPE) must be available to workers. Workers should be trained in the use and maintenance of personal and collective protective equipment. PPE is the last line of defence and the least effective. Where there are still some residual risks that cannot be reduced by other means, the employer should provide appropriate PPE, such as coveralls, gloves, goggles, safety boots and hearing protectors.
Trade Union Representation

"Strong trade union organisation is essential to ensure that employers prevent injuries, ill health, and death of working people and others in the wider community.\n" "One of the main jobs of trade unions and their members at a local level is to make sure that the employer keeps to her/his responsibilities. Some of the ways to achieve this include building a strong membership, electing worker HS&E representatives and organising for health, safety and the environment.\n"
The job of a Worker HS&E Representative

"The term ‘worker HS&E representative’ covers a number of different categories of representative. The IUF believes that any worker HS&E representative should be a trade union representative selected or elected by fellow union members in their workplace.
" "In Article 8.1 (b) of ILO Convention No. 184 the workers have a right to select safety and health representatives. The main jobs that a worker HS&E representative include is:
" 
 • talking to members, and taking up their complaints with management
 • involving, informing, and consulting members
 • collecting and distributing HS&E information
 • identifying hazards, investigating and tackling the risks
 • investigating OSH incidents, ill health and near-misses
 • checking that the employer is complying with health and safety requirements
 • consulting and negotiating with management
Governments and their Obligations

"Trade unions believe that Governments have a critical role to play in the protection of workers’ health. They should:
" 
 • ratify ILO Convention No. 184 on Safety and Health in Agriculture 2001
 • develop a coherent national policy on health, safety and the environment, in consultation with trade unions and employers
 • as a minimum, pass laws based upon ILO Convention No. 184 on Safety and Health in Agriculture 2001
 • create an adequately resourced inspectorate to enforce the law
Employers and their Obligations

"Employers have the primary legal responsibility to protect the health, safety and welfare of workers. Trade unions believe that deaths, injuries and ill health are caused because employers fail to provide a safe and healthy working environment.
" "The employer should provide:
" 
 • a working environment where hazards are identified, risks are assessed, removed or controlled before problems occur
 • a working environment where early action is taken to prevent harm
 • safe systems of working
 • workplaces that are adapted to the needs of the worker
 • full information to and consultation with workers and their unions
 • good health and safety training programmes
 • opportunities for workers through their unions, to negotiate health and safety clauses in collective agreements, and participate actively in health and safety matters
 • policies that address the impact of work upon the wider environment
 
 "So employers should reduce injuries and ill health by:
" 
 • identifying hazards
 • evaluating, assessing and prioritizing risks
 • tackling the risks at source by elimination, substitution and prevention/control
 • effectively managing health, safety and the environment
Workers and HS&E

"Trade unions have got a role in raising awareness but cannot stop injuries or ill health just by making workers more safety conscious:
" 
 • all hazards and consequent risks are obvious – especially damage to health over a period of time
 • workers may not be properly trained or informed
 • stress, tiredness and poor conditions can all lead to the risk of injury or ill health
 • workers are human – they do make errors, but a small error should not cost someone their life or result in serious injury
 
 "Article 8 1 (b) of ILO Convention No. 184 on Safety and Health in Agriculture 2001 gives workers the right to remove themselves from danger where there is a serious and imminent risk, and not be penalised for these actions.
" "The basic three workers right on OHS are clearly set by ILO Convention 184 on health and safety in agriculture:
Article 8.1. Workers in agriculture shall have the right:
" 
 (a) to be informed and consulted on safety and health matters including risks from new technologies;
 (b) to participate in the application and review of safety and health measures and, in accordance with national law and practice, to select safety and health representatives and representatives in safety and health committees; and
 (c) to remove themselves from danger resulting from their work activity when they have reasonable justification to believe there is an imminent and serious risk to their safety and health and so inform their supervisor immediately. They shall not be placed at any disadvantage as a result of these actions.
 
 "But workers also have some obligations that include:
" 
 • observing health, safety and environmental regulations
 • carrying out work safely in a manner that does not endanger themselves and others
 • attending HS&E training
 • using equipment for HS&E including suitable personal protective equipment (PPE) where necessary
 • reporting dangerous situations

"What-if? is a simple technique for identifying and preventing risks. It consists in evaluating the flow of the process, needing to be carried out by people who know the activity well.\n" "For each activity to be evaluated, an adverse event is questioned and it may suggest possible causes and consequences and preventive measures to avoid or control the risk.\n"
Activity
Insert here the work activity
What If
Insert here which adverse/problem event may occur when performing the activity
Causes
Insert possible causes here for this adverse event
Consequences
Insert here what possible damages to the worker may occur
Measures
Insert here corrective measures to avoid the adverse event and protect the worker

COVID-19
What is SARS-COV-2?
Symptoms
Transmission
Protection
What do you have to know about Masks
Other protection measures

• Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is caused by a newly discovered virus. 

 • The ICTV (International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses) officially designated the name of the new coronavirus as SARS-COV-2 virus (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome). 

 • The Coronaviridae family has different types of coronavirus. Some cause severe respiratory diseases, and are called SARS-COV, as SARS-COV (China 2002/2003) and MERS-COV (Middle East, Saudi Arabia 2012).
Common Symptoms
Severe Symptoms

• Fever
 • Tiredness
 • Loss of Smell
 • Dry Cough

• High fever
 • Pneumonia
 • Difficulty Breathing

"• Clean and disinfect boots.
 • (‘Footbath’).
 • Remove work clothes before leaving the farm.
 • Wash your hands with soap and water.
 • Dry your hands with paper towel.
 • No personal protective equipment should be shared or loaned, even after disinfection.
 • If possible, take a shower before you go home (or as soon as you arrive).
 • Put clean clothes, kept in an enclosed space.
 • Avoid using personal items, such as cell phones, in production/work areas.
 • Use appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).
 • Restrict access to unnecessary people on farms and production and processing sites.
 • Avoid unnecessary and unprotected contact with [wild] animals.
 • Wash hands after contact with animals or animal products.
 • Stay home if you are feeling ill.
 • If you have a fever, cough or difficulty breathing, seek medical attention.
"
"How to protect the workplace and workers using hierarchy control?"
"How can employers improve a workplace safety?"
How to protect yourself
Which mask should I use?
Non-surgical masks
How to use it?
Care with the use of the mask
Care with the use of the fabric mask
Attention to disposal of masks

"1. Risk Elimination and Substitution Controls include quarantine and isolation, which means one worker at time.

 2. Engineering controls include install physical barriers between workers, mainly if they work side-by-side. In this context, worker should stay 2m (6 feets) far from each other.

 3. Administrative controls include: • training for workers on the use of workers on the use of Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) and others safety measures. • Control the temperature of the workers.

 4. Personal Protection Equipment (PPE): • Using masks in all activities (provided by the employer); • Use face shield, over the mask, in fishing and harvest activities and those involving splashing water.

"

"• Make sure the workplaces are clean and sanitized.

 • Surfaces need to be cleaned with disinfectant regularly, because contamination on surfaces touched by employees and customers is one of the ways in which the coronavirus spreads.

 • Place hand sanitizer (gel alcohol) dispensers in prominent locations in the workplace.

 • Display posters promoting hand washing.

 • Make sure people have access to places where they can wash their hands with soap and water.

 • Install a footbath (footwash) at the entrance to farms and closed places, such as laboratories, places where they perform nursery, breeding, spawning, etc.

 • Make sure the workers keep 2 meters of distance between each other.

 • Producers, workers and collaborators of the risk group (over 60 years old, people with medical problems, such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, chronic respiratory diseases and cancer), must remain at home.

"

"1. Prefer washing your hands with soap and water

 2. Clean hands with alcohol gel

 3. Do not touch your face

 4. When coughing or sneezing, practice the breathing tag (cough in one arm with your elbow flexed)

 5. Avoid physical contact (hugs, handshakes and kisses should be avoided)

"

"• N95 masks may be scarce and should only be used for healthcare workers in contact with infected or suspected patients with COVID-19.

 • Some studies show that surgical masks have high efficiency in retaining viral particles.

 • Homemade masks with 3 layers of fabric also showed good efficiency.

 • Do not use masks with front ‘stitching’. The front seam dramatically decreases protection.

 • Do not touch the mask.

"
In non-surgical masks, the following should be considered:

"• Masks should be at least 3 layers of fabric.

 • Breathability of the material used.

 • Do not pass water through the fabric.

 • Shape of the mask.

 • Mask adjustment.

"

"• Put the mask on carefully, making sure it covers your mouth and nose, and tie it tightly to minimize any gap between your face and the mask.

 • Avoid touching it when using.

 • Change the mask as soon as it gets wet with a clean, dry mask.

 • Do not reuse single-use masks.

"

"• Remove the mask using the appropriate technique: do not touch the front of the mask, untie it at the back.
 • After removal or whenever a mask is touched inadvertently, clean your hands using alcohol gel or soap and water if your hands are visibly soiled.

" HOW SHOULD I REMOVE THE MASK? "

1. Wash your hands: wash your hands before touching the mask.
 2. How should I remove the mask? Remove the mask by holding the elastics/ties, without touching the front of the mask as it may be contaminated.
 3. Wash your hands again: wash your hands after remove the mask.
 4. Wash the mask: put it to wash as soon as possible.
 5. Keep the mask: if you cannot wash at the moment, keep it in a closed bag.

"
How should I wash the mask?

"• Sanitary water: after use, soak in sanitary water for 20 minutes.

 • Water and soap: Then, wash with soap and water.

 • Wash separately: Wash the mask separately from other clothes.

 • Ironing the mask: after drying, it is recommended to ironing with hot iron.

 • Keep the mask: keep the mask in a clean and dry place.

"

"• Masks that do not come from health services should be disposed of in regular garbage (not recyclable).

 • Remove the mask and place in a separate bag.

 • Discard immediately in a closed bin;

"

"• Handshake
 • Saliva droplets
 • Cough
 • Sneeze

" Contaminated objects such as: "

• Cellphones
 • Tables
 • Door Handle
 • Toys
 • Computer keyboards
 • etc...
"
